Can anybody name the significance Schrodinger had in the field of quatum mechanics? What was his major contribution to science?

schrodinger made the schrodinger wave equation 
 
 this took into account the wave like and particle like properties of electrons 
 
 when solving the equation you get wave functions that describe the matter wave of an electron
 
 
 thats all i know
What did he do for QM? I am uncertain.:D

QM gets no more fundamental than the 2 slit interference experiment and Schrondinger's uncertainity principle. Lasers, computers, transistors, DNA, etc get their start from the understanding those two phenomena.

Originally posted by Crim 
 That's the Heisenburg Uncertainty Principle. 
 
 ]
 
 Whoops? Are you sure?:p
isnt that when you cant know the position and energy of the electron and a single instant???
You can't know the exact position and momentum at the same time. The more you know of one, the less you know of the other.

matter is the central manifestation of a distortion in the universal field. In order to sustain itself in a state of universal entropy matter must draw energy from this universal field. The effect of this is time space curviture. Gravity is the act of stealing time and space. Apples do not fall from trees the timespace between them disapears.
 
 The problem with the dual nature of energy/matter and its given location with in the continueum is the same as the problem of light speed. That is the universe consists of overlaping distortions with in the contiumeum, ergo there is no induvidual point in time space that has the identical properties of time and space dilation. It was Einstiene that postulated properties would only ever be relitive to the observer.
 
 One is therfore left to difine time and space in ones mind. This is why when asked a spesific question regarding its nature energy/matter always answers in which context are you asking. The problem with science is the phylisophical constraints of the absolute and reductionism.
